g.text: Notice that each curve resembles a shifted and stretched sine function.
By looking at the blue curve we see that, at the latitude of Philadelphia, daylight
lasts about 14.8 hours on June 21 and 9.2 hours on December 21, so the amplitude
of the curve (the factor by which we have to stretch the sine curve vertically) is
By what factor do we need to stretch the sine curve horizontally if we measure the
in days? Because there are about 365 days in a year, the period of our model
should be 365. But the period of
We also notice that the curve begins its cycle on March 21, the 80th day of the
year, so we have to shift the curve 80 units to the right. ±n addition, we shift it 12 units
upward. Therefore we model the length of daylight in Philadelphia on the
Another transformation of some interest is taking the
, then according to the deInition of absolute value,
0. This tells us how to get the graph of

downward 1 unit. We see that the graph lies below the

can be combined to form new functions
in a manner similar to the way we add, subtract, multiply, and divide real numbers. The
sum and difference functions are deIned by
have to be deIned. For example, the domain
Similarly, the product and quotient functions are deIned by
, but we can’t divide by 0 and so the domain of
There is another way of combining two functions to obtain a new function. For
is, in turn, a function of
